Jim Blandings.Action: Jim Blandings wrote the successful advertising slogan 'When you've got the whim, say Wham!'
Lives harmoniously with his wife Muriel in a small, cluttered bedroom, suggesting a shared, comfortable domestic life.
Sleepily navigates his crowded bedroom with careful, gentle movements, indicating a patient and tolerant nature.
Writes a catchy and effective advertising slogan: 'When you've got the whim, say Wham!'
Navigates the cluttered bedroom in a sleepy, practiced but somewhat clumsy way, illustrating habitual routine rather than active skill or alertness.

Yawns, dozes off while trying to start the day, fumbles around looking for bathrobe and slippers, pulls on the wrong robe and clumsily stuffs it back causing dresses to fall, then finds his robe under the dresses.
Knocks before entering children's rooms, showing respect for privacy.
Automatically pulls the covers off Joan's bed, waking her gently.
Makes a feeble attempt at a smile to Gussie; accepts care from cook.
Navigates household traffic with care and patience around his children.
Ruffles through drawers noisily and cannot find his socks despite looking in underwear and sock drawers, even pulling out Muriel's silk slips by mistake.
Expresses restrained patience and tries to clarify the drawer arrangement and communicate about shared space and organization.
Relies on Muriel and Gussie's decision about where to keep socks in a basket on the closet shelf, showing lack of personal system or control over his belongings.
Struggles with clumsiness but tries to accommodate Muriel's wishes.
Barely contains anger and frustration but responds politely to Muriel.
Responds irritably to Joan’s scream but still greets her politely.
Shows annoyance and scowl when intruded upon in the bathroom.

Carefully smoothes out the toothpaste tube, tries to keep the medicine cabinet orderly, catches falling bottles, thoughtfully discards old medicine, puts on shower cap with care, sings happily in the shower.
Meticulously smoothes out toothpaste tube and rolls it up from the bottom.
Catches multiple items falling out of overcrowded medicine cabinet while brushing teeth.
Carefully dries inside of shower cap before putting it back on wet hair.
Throws out a bottle of cough medicine after contemplating its value in an overcrowded cabinet, showing practical decision-making.
Tries to shave efficiently in a cramped, awkward bathroom situation, showing persistence and adaptability despite inconveniences.
Shows impatience toward Muriel when she delays him while he is shaving, indicating some lack of patience and social tact.
Gives up on using a razor initially, nicking himself, but then manages to finish shaving with a few deft strokes.
Irritably dismisses Muriel’s practical suggestion of using an electric razor without fully considering it.
Notices and carefully tidies the squeezed toothpaste tube and catches the falling iodine bottle, then thoughtfully devises a solution before closing the mirror door.
Listens quietly to Betsy reading the ad but shows impatience and dismisses the emotional context, minimizing others' feelings.
Uses sarcasm and dismissive remarks towards the advertising profession and the emotional significance of the ad.
Listens calmly but dismisses the emotional and humanitarian context of the advertisement, showing limited insight or empathy.
Responds with controlled sarcasm to Joan’s comment on advertising, maintaining composure and engaging in the discussion.
Sarcastically dismisses criticism of advertising profession; complains about paying for family expenses
Responds to Muriel's request not to discuss money in front of children with a joking retort
Avoids or ignores Muriel’s nervousness about visitor Mr. Funkhauser, showing little engagement
Expresses skepticism and irritation about the designer and the 'zebra-striped monstrosity' in the Collins' living room.
Quietly jokes about the unlikelihood of two people with the same uncommon name (Bunny Funkhauser).
Questions the competence of the designer by referencing a known poor design ('that zebra-striped monstrosity'), showing discernment and skepticism.
Interrupts and gets angry about a potentially bad financial decision ('Phil Collins told me what he paid'), indicating frustration but also awareness of costs.
Seems blank and distasteful when first confronted with the arrival of the designer, showing detachment and possibly lack of control over the situation.
Responds with a dark look to Muriel but refrains from conflict during Funkhauser’s intrusive decorating ideas.
Politely questions the cost and practicality of the renovations, showing concern without rudeness.
Responds appallingly to the suggestion of bright colors with a lame joke, showing slight discomfort but trying to be polite.
Politely but firmly asks for a clear cost figure despite the decorator's evasiveness.
Makes a lame joke about backing off color, showing some discomfort but attempts to engage with humor.
Appalled reaction to bold color choices without constructive suggestions.
Considers cost fairly and tries to tactfully manage an awkward conversation with Funkhauser, ending politely by putting Funkhauser's hat on his head and thanking him.
Dismisses the idea of spending money on the house with sarcasm and cynicism after Funkhauser leaves.
Attempts to establish an overall figure with Funkhauser and agrees to a rough estimate, then quickly moves to end the meeting and postpone detailed discussion.
Dismisses Funkhauser’s concern about premature cost discussion, showing some impulsiveness and lack of thoroughness.
Shows some social tact by politeness in ending the meeting and handling Funkhauser’s departure smoothly.
Argues vehemently and dismissively with Muriel, shows frustration over money and house issues, storms out slamming the door.
Looks guiltily at Muriel's photograph and says 'Sorry' after their argument.
Vehemently argues about the cost and practicality of the apartment, showing strong opinion but no clear skill or effective problem-solving.
Jerks open closet door and unwittingly causes hat boxes and items to fall on his head, showing clumsiness and lack of carefulness.
Despite emotional upset, enters his office and looks at his advertising handiwork showing prior professional success and skill, indicating competence in his career.
Looks guiltily at photograph of Muriel, then apologizes silently.
Responds briefly and blankly to secretary Mary, not engaging warmly.
Focuses thoughtfully on countryside ad, showing interest in a peaceful life, possibly reflecting sincere hopes.
Drives with Muriel, communicating nonverbally a reassuring 'just wait and see' gesture.
Pats Muriel's hand affectionately, looks at her for approval, and shares a warm moment.
Cautiously tempers Muriel's enthusiasm about the old house, signaling realism and consideration.
Presents a casual, somewhat indifferent attitude about the house, maintaining honesty and openness.
Cautiously downplays enthusiasm for a charming old house by noting its age and emphasizing they are only 'window shopping'; studies house with assumed indifference.
Looks to Muriel's over-enthusiasm and subtly signals caution, attempting to manage expectations.
Shows genuine interest and enthusiasm about the history of the house.
Shares the historical significance of General Gates with Muriel in an engaged manner.
Nods thoughtfully and envisions the potential improvements for the house.
Puts arm tenderly around Muriel's waist while both look affectionately at the house.
Responds to Muriel's excitement about the house with quiet enthusiasm and careful control, instructing others to be quiet and let him handle the situation.
Engages in friendly, polite conversation with Smith and Eph Hackett, showing openness and cordiality.
Sings gaily and interacts jovially with family at breakfast
Announces decisively he will make a decision on his own to spare legal advice
Responds darkly/suspiciously to Muriel’s concerns about real estate offer
Decides to make a significant financial decision (offering ten thousand dollars) on his own without consulting professional advice, dismissing the counsel of a trusted lawyer friend.
Attempts to maintain a cheerful, confident demeanor (singing gaily) despite underlying tensions about the house purchase.
Responds to modern house ideas with restraint and mild sarcasm, defends the dignity of their current house, shows excitement and disappointment about letter regarding house offer
Firmly negotiates to not pay more than a set price on the house despite pressures.

Corresponds amicably and repeatedly with Mr. Smith using friendly salutations like 'Dear Friend Blandings' and 'My dear Friend Smith,' showing a desire for cordial relations despite difficult negotiations.
Reaches out to his wife Muriel for support during stressful negotiations, embracing her and involving her in the effort.
Feels pride and faces the reality of being swindled with a degree of good-natured acceptance rather than bitterness or blame.
Fails to notice he has overpaid significantly for land and is unaware of hidden terms reducing acreage; challenges others without evidence.
Attempts to defend his purchase and insists on fairness to the seller, showing some basic understanding of business ethics.
On the defensive about the property acreage, insists on intangible values like antique significance.
Dismisses Bill's criticism by saying 'You don't understand business.'
Shows rising emotion and refuses to pressure Hackett indirectly through a letter.
Expresses frustration about cramped living conditions to explain his eagerness for the new house.
Expresses heartfelt enthusiasm and love for the dream house, shares tender moment with Muriel, squeezes her hand intimately in courthouse
Expresses emotional commitment to the dream house, focusing on love and passion rather than practical financial considerations.
Confidently plans to sign the purchase papers, embracing ownership despite potential risks mentioned by others.
Interrupts the judge to question the acreage, showing concern and directness.
Gives Bill a sour look after Bill downplays the acreage discrepancy.
Interrupts the judge to ask for clarification about the acreage, showing attentiveness to important details.
Questions the property size discrepancy with the seller, demonstrates awareness and concern about the transaction.
Relies on Bill's confirmation and expertise rather than contesting or handling the legal/mapping details himself.
Disagrees with Muriel on which road to take and repeatedly drives the car left despite her protests, showing annoyance but ultimately continuing the journey with resignation and shared disgust.
Drives the car repeatedly onto the wrong road, circling back to the same covered bridge multiple times despite Muriel's suggestions to go another direction.
Shows annoyance and frustration with being lost, but does not adapt effectively to the situation.
Looks at Muriel with disgust and resignation during confusion about directions.
Listens quietly and lets others speak about the house and lilacs in admiration.
Defends the house’s old foundation with nostalgic pride despite obvious damage, showing attachment.
Dismisses the engineer's concerns about the old house's foundation and roof, relying on the house's historical longevity instead of expert opinion.
Drives deliberately in response to Bill's hint, demonstrating some practical problem-solving in navigation.
Politely declines Bill's offer but invites him inside to look around.
Gives his word to trust Apollonio's advice.
Maintains hopeful enthusiasm with family despite apparent house problems.
Acknowledges the specialized expertise of a structural engineer and seriously considers involving him.
Insists on handling the inspection himself despite visible structural problems and danger (shingles falling, roof instability).

After the engineer inspects the house and finds severe termite damage, Jim remains hopeful and tries to focus on maintaining the character and functionality of the house, showing some positive planning perspective.
Limps over thoughtfully and follows Muriel to the expert's side; listens attentively to Apollonio's opinion about the house.
Responds coolly and bitterly to Apollonio's recommendation to tear down the house but does not argue aggressively or insult him.
Responds coolly and listens to expert opinion about the house's condition despite being appalled by the recommendation to tear it down.
Initially shows some emotional reaction (appalled) but maintains composure and engages professionally with the expert.
Relies on experts' advice to evaluate his house instead of making uninformed decisions.
Smiles feebly and looks considerably shaken by the unanimous expert advice to tear down the house.
Considers building a new house thoughtfully and includes Muriel in decision-making.
Nervously nibbling at his nails during discussion of house condition.
Listens thoughtfully to Simms' assessment and considers the idea of a new house.
Engages Muriel for her opinion and discusses options with Simms cautiously and tentatively.
Shares ideas about the house plan, shows willingness to collaborate with Muriel and Simms despite some impatience.
Gently insists on a reasonably sized playroom, but defers to Muriel's wishes and includes her ideas in the plans.
Repeatedly competes with Muriel and Simms for control of the pencil while planning the house.
Takes initiative in discussions by reaching for the pencil first, actively participates in planning the house, proposes practical ideas for the playroom and terrace, attempts to steer conversation.
Seems to engage in a somewhat chaotic planning session with Muriel and Simms, with conflicting ideas and multiple interruptions, ending in visible exhaustion and a confusing, overly altered plan.
Jovially puts his arm around Simms' shoulders while maintaining friendly conversation despite cost concerns.
Makes a rueful joke about blowing up the old house, displaying light-heartedness and ease with others.
Expresses understanding and acceptance of cost overrun without quibbling, showing tolerance and goodwill.
Shares a resigned sigh about the rising costs with Muriel and maintains a collaborative tone discussing budget cuts.
Reassures Muriel by echoing Simms' technical explanation patiently, addressing her concerns.
Responds to Muriel's confusion patiently but with mild irritation, tries to maintain authority in discussion but shows some awkwardness and insecurity.
Defends the need for separate rooms for daughters thoughtfully, showing concern for his family’s needs.
Rejects eliminating the playroom which his wife finds ridiculous, asserting his need for relaxation, despite his wife's suggestion to garden.
Dismisses Muriel's concern about children's health by telling them to 'rough it' with fewer bathrooms.
Laughs loudly and makes fun of Mrs. Bildad Prutty and the Lansdale Historical Society's efforts.
Shares amusing newspaper news with family, showing a humorous and informal side.
Dismisses Muriel's concern about needing four bathrooms, suggesting the children can 'rough it' with three bathrooms to save money.
Attempts to cut costs on house features by arguing practical reductions.
Engages with the newspaper article in a humorous, somewhat careless manner, not fully appreciating the seriousness of the subject.
Responds weakly to financial misunderstanding, tells Muriel to put children to bed to avoid conflict
Dismisses Bill Cole's serious concerns with a casual and somewhat confrontational response ('What if he did? What of it?')
Encourages Simms to proceed with plans despite difficulties, showing willingness to persevere for family
Shows irritation when Muriel expresses concern about cashing insurance policies, responding sharply
Expresses concern about collateral yet tries to handle responsibility without burdening others
Expresses annoyance and jealousy over Bill's affectionate behavior toward his wife Muriel, showing protectiveness.
Testily insists that Bill's behavior is inappropriate and expresses discomfort with their friendship boundaries.
Sighs and accepts Muriel's comforting gesture and perspective, showing openness and reconciliation.
Shares an intimate smile and kiss with Muriel while discussing their future home together.
Playfully comments about bathroom crowding, showing a light-hearted rapport with Muriel.
Immediately dismisses Simms' attempt to explain estimates, showing impatience.
Confidently takes the sheet of estimates without listening to explanation, claiming he is 'an old hand at this sort of—'
Reacts with surprise and alarm at the high bids, showing awareness of cost implications
Hands estimates to Simms and asks for a bill, showing readiness to pay and responsibility.
Takes Muriel's hand and leaves with her, showing connection and support.
Jokes about getting his head examined and jumping off the Brooklyn Bridge, revealing his stress but also sharing it openly with Muriel.
Face softens when seeing the drawing of their house, showing sentimental and affectionate feelings.
Hands estimates to Simms and asks him to send a bill for services; attempts to stay composed amid stressful cost overruns.
Expresses frustration with costs by saying he is going to get his head examined and contemplate signing a long lease instead of building, indicating self-awareness of the difficulty ahead.
Softens when viewing the drawing of his prospective house and quietly inquires about the contractor, showing attention to detail and desire to proceed thoughtfully.
Does not dispute the high bids or aggressively negotiate with contractors at this stage but seems somewhat overwhelmed by the rising costs.
Shows unconcealed pride and excitement about their property despite noisy construction.
Explains to Bill the decision about having an artesian well instead of the trout stream, defensively but sincerely.
Responds confidently and with pride when observing the construction site, managing noisy chaos with a positive attitude ('things are certainly humming').
Shows lack of full awareness by continuing to shout over the noise even after a sudden silent pause ('unaware of it, continues to shout').
Gropes to defend decision about well choice, indicating uncertainty ('groping', 'I decided against it... didn’t seem practical').
Approaches the group around the steam shovel to understand the problem, asks Mr. Zucca questions calmly
Frowns and seems annoyed when Muriel sarcastically thanks Bill for carrying her over the trench
Shows concern about the cost of blasting and quietly resigns to the challenges of building the house.
Irritably asks how long the noisy work will continue, then asserts authority by deciding to talk to the well-digger.
Politely tries to clarify and understand the progress of the work by asking Tesander questions, showing patient engagement despite initial miscommunication
Looks to Muriel for comfort and support when uncertain, indicating openness and reliance on family
Shouts to get Tesander's attention repeatedly but does so in a generally patient and non-confrontational manner
Asks detailed questions about progress of the drilling, seeks clarification about technical details.
Appears confused about the significance of geological terms (limestone, shale, sandstone), looks to others for reassurance.
Tries to intervene by suggesting trying another spot despite limited understanding.
Warmly greets Bill Cole, invites him in enthusiastically.
Impatiently reacts to Bill's indirect way of addressing the problem.
Shakes Bill's hand absently despite distracted mood.
Soberly discusses situation with Mary, shows openness and seriousness.
Explains the layout of the unfinished house patiently despite confusion.
Follows the carpenter's instructions without fully understanding, tries to avoid conflict, looks to wife for support.
Responds sheepishly after realizing his mistake, admits uncertainty.
Fails to understand construction terminology and makes an uninformed decision leading to costly rework.
Attempts to participate in decision-making on house construction despite lack of expertise.
Tries to calm the workmen after Muriel's remark, attempting to keep the job going despite a tense situation.
Fails to anticipate or prevent the conflict with the workmen resulting from Muriel's outburst, causing a work stoppage.
Expresses disbelief to Bill about being locked in a closet he had personally designed to avoid that exact issue, showing a lack of practical insight.
Tries to demonstrate how to open the closet lock with confidence, shows a bit of conceit and impatience when it fails, then seeks help by calling out loudly for assistance.
Reassures Muriel calmly that he will get her out of the closet, taking charge to break the window despite some risk
Mutters to himself about the lock not working, showing a private moment of mild frustration but no blame shifting
Enters breakfast nook in high spirits and tries to lighten mood by improvising music
Responds affirmatively to Joan's request for a basement chemistry lab despite being preoccupied.
Engages in mild bickering with Muriel about Bill driving her places, showing some irritation but also concern.
Explodes emotionally upon reading a letter, immediately acting to defend his rights by calling Bill Cole.
Preoccupiedly agrees to daughter's request without considering implications.
Expresses suspicion and annoyance about Bill Cole's involvement without seeking clarification calmly.
Reacts emotionally by crumpling a letter and immediately calls Bill Cole to confront him sharply and assertively.
Demonstrates confusion and frustration, not fully explaining his concerns clearly, leading to apparent domestic tension.
Fights the illegal thirty-day move notice despite challenges, insists on staying until house is ready, then complies quietly after discussion with Muriel
Impatiently honks and gestures at moving vans when they take the wrong road
Jim and Muriel exchange a warm intimate smile upon seeing their Dream House, showing affection and shared pride.
At the door, Jim indicates he’d like to carry Muriel across the threshold, showing romantic and caring behavior.
Starts to pick up Muriel despite playful protest, displaying a warm, affectionate gesture.
Stops the car to take in and appreciate the nearly completed house, shows emotional connection and pride.
Indicates he would like to carry Muriel across the threshold, showing traditional and affectionate behavior.
Manages to lift Muriel despite not having done this sort of thing for fifteen years, showing some physical capability.
Walks over freshly varnished floor ignoring warning sign, causing damage and confrontation with the painter.
Responds quickly by demanding painter put down planks to protect the floor, demonstrating problem-solving.
Fails to notice or heed the 'WET VARNISH' sign before stepping on the floor, indicating lack of attention to detail.
Expresses frustration over mix-up with windows but listens to explanation patiently.
Explodes at unexpected charge for water softener but reluctantly agrees when told it's necessary.
Shows irritation and sharpness toward workers despite their efforts to solve problems.
Disappears for an hour during a critical moment when heavy dishes were to be handled, causing disruption.
Leans against the wall with Bill in bored and disgusted silence after being locked in a closet; exchanges terse blame with Muriel
Expresses frustration about inconvenient train schedule affecting his routine, involving family in the discussion
Sharp retort about early rising and catching the train
Says goodbye to Bill though preoccupied and distracted
Vaguely annoyed at children's conversation about Bill's vacation but covers it up and encourages them to get busy
Backs away coughing from the smoky fireplace and then scolds children for the mess spilling Muriel's sentimental trinkets.
Tells children to clean up the sentimental trinkets and help set the table, putting family duties first.
Firmly enforces boundaries with his children regarding privacy (sharply telling them not to read the diary) and quickly takes charge of cleaning up instead of leaving it to them.
Displays curiosity and breaks his own rule by secretly reading the diary after the children leave, showing inconsistency between his stated values and actions.
Responds to Muriel's concern with irritability and accusations about falsehood and deception.
Accuses Muriel of jealousy and confronts her about the pin and her past feelings, including reading her diary without permission.
Jim sincerely apologizes to Muriel for acting like a schoolboy.
Jim gently turns Muriel around to face him and tenderly kisses her, showing affection despite earlier tension.
Jim persistently calls out to Muriel despite her initial silence, showing patience and concern.
Approaches conflict with Muriel by apologizing sincerely and tenderly, showing emotional intelligence and a capacity to mend the relationship.
Repeatedly tries to engage Muriel despite her initial silence, showing perseverance but also a somewhat tentative and unsure approach.
Responds to Muriel's teasing and affection with warmth and tenderness, demonstrating relational competence.
Shows brief acceptance of responsibility with a resigned sigh, indicating practical awareness but possible passivity.
Says goodnight to Muriel quietly and respectfully, each going to their own bed.
Acknowledges the stressful situation at work and shares it with Mary without complaint, showing openness and sincerity.
Reflects aloud on small, simple pleasures like the rain, showing thoughtful and sincere sensitivity.
Considers logic and agrees to get up early despite reluctance.
Observes the escalating cost of the house with concern but does not indicate a plan to control expenses.
Prepares to work late into the night to meet a deadline, showing dedication and persistence.
Acknowledges pressure about his upcoming task, indicating awareness of stakes.
Appears thoughtful and contemplative, taking time to reflect before acting.
Reacting with weariness and no clear immediate solution presented for the problematic situation.
Shows frustration and weariness but gently interacts with Mary by trying out advertising lines and seeking her reaction
Struggles to light a cigarette and burns his nose, showing frustration and physical clumsiness.
Thinks thoughtfully by the window, gets an idea, and actively tries to create advertising slogans for Wham despite difficulties.
Repeatedly tries different slogans and seeks feedback from Mary, showing persistence and willingness to improve.
Appears weary, absently plays with his loosened tie, and seems defeated at times.
Reviews previous work carefully and indicates some approval, then tries again to produce better ideas.
Looks at his family photograph with affection when feeling distraught
Expresses frustration and anger at his professional struggles
Acts sharply and abruptly to Mary when discussing job situation
Decides to go home to rest and advises Mary to do the same
Greets Muriel with a kiss and embraces her when talking to Simms.
Responds unenthusiastically and with some distraction when Muriel inquires about his day.
Makes lighthearted jokes about small extra charges in the building expenses.
Reacts explosively to unexpected bill but then listens to explanation about the 'flower sink' change; shows suspicion toward Muriel's actions, repeatedly questions her.
Looks suspiciously at Muriel and reviews the bill and blueprints carefully to understand unexpected charges, questioning discrepancies.
Reactively challenges Muriel about unauthorized changes and tries to get clarity on what was done.
Despite initial explosive reaction, pursues factual understanding rather than jumping to conclusions.
Reacts to Muriel's admission by trying to manage the situation calmly, taking a deep breath before addressing Simms, despite visible frustration toward Muriel.
Takes a deep breath and directly asks Simms for an explanation after discovering a construction issue.
Glares at Muriel as if premeditating first-degree murder after hearing about the drainage problem, showing emotional reaction rather than calm problem-solving.
Commands silence with a firm 'Quiet!' when Muriel tries to interrupt, indicating taking control of the situation.
Acknowledges Bill Cole's presence despite surprise, looks to Muriel for explanation, responds politely to Bill's cheerfulness.
Shows mild shock but refrains from negative reaction to Bill's unexpected overnight stay.
Looks puzzled and seeks explanation from Muriel about Bill's presence in pajamas, reacting with mild shock but not taking immediate control or initiative.
Responds politely and cheerily to Bill after learning he slept there due to circumstances beyond control, showing social grace but not technical or managerial skill.
Expresses frustration and despair over the house project, yet shows sincere vulnerability about his lost happiness and values his family’s love and trust.
Explodes in anger blaming everyone involved in building the house, using harsh generalizations and conspiratorial language.
Generously offers all his money and help to Tesander in a playful, open-hearted manner.
Shows sheepishness and guilt when unexpectedly given money back by Tesander, reflecting sincerity and humility.
Acts impulsively and generously without verifying facts; reacts with embarrassment and confusion when corrected about the money owed.
Sheepishly asks Bill to be patient with him, shows vulnerability.
Appears miserable and unsure when Muriel asks about financial difficulties.
Greets children warmly as they come in, exchanging 'Hi's.
Does not retaliate when Bill jokes about counting the silverware; instead shares a look with Muriel and admits he’s on a kind of vacation.
Expresses uncertainty and misery about financial troubles, does not have clear answers for his family.
Acknowledges his immaturity and asks for patience, showing self-awareness but also lack of confidence.
Reacts with enthusiasm to Gussie's cheerful cooking effort; immediately suggests giving her a raise.
With simple sincerity, invites others to drop in and see them sometime.
Leaves Muriel's dresses fallen on the floor after accidentally knocking them down, but looks guilty and closes the closet door quietly.
Uses Muriel's bathrobe by mistake and tries to put it back carefully.
Knocks before entering rooms, shows polite and considerate behavior toward family members.
Automatically pulls covers off his sleeping daughter without waking her harshly; moves carefully and with good timing to avoid collisions with children rushing past.
Makes a feeble attempt at a smile suggesting low energy or lack of confidence.
Nudges Muriel gently to wake her and brings her coffee, shares a brief affectionate kiss.
Expresses annoyance but interacts patiently and restrained while searching for his socks.
Mentions the drawer space issue to Muriel, somewhat blaming Gussie indirectly.
Engages in a playful, slightly irritable but intimate conversation with Muriel about shaving habits.
Shows impatience and irritation (glaring, folded arms, irritable tone) when interrupted before breakfast.
Meticulously smoothes out and carefully stores toothpaste and catches iodine bottle to prevent mess.
Reacted with pained but controlled exasperation when Betsy cut out newspaper sections without permission, then reminded her not to do so.
Engaged in a sarcastic remark about Betsy's school project but did not escalate or show harshness.
Engages with Betsy about her school assignment despite initial reluctance, showing effort to listen.
Uses sarcasm and dismissive phrases ('Bicker, bicker, bicker', 'You eat your cornflakes!') during family discussion.
Expresses desire to have a simple breakfast without social implications, indicating some frustration but also openness.
Reacting with 'painful resignation' and eventually agrees to listen to Betsy.
Responds to Joan's remark with elaborate sarcasm.
Considers leaving his profession despite it paying for his family's expenses.
Dismisses discussing money in front of children, showing disregard for social sensitivity.
Remains preoccupied with his paper and seems unaware or inattentive when Mr. Funkhauser arrives and is announced.
Asks who Mr. Funkhauser is despite being reminded about him, showing forgetfulness or inattentiveness.
Listens to Funkhauser's design ideas and reacts with a dark look; is cautious or skeptical but does not undermine the discussion.
Nonchalantly holds a shotgun in the most precisely correct position, proudly surveying his property.
Wondering what was meant by 'steal' with a thoughtful 'Hm.'
Shows tenderness and affection by putting his arm around Muriel's waist while visualizing the house.
Confidently handles negotiating tone by telling Muriel to 'let me handle this' and assures her they can get the house easily ('like taking candy from a baby').
Firmly insists Funkhauser should not be involved with the house renovation.
Displays casual, somewhat noncommittal attitude by saying 'I guess it doesn't hurt to take a look' when asked about visiting the house.
Attempts to negotiate or express interest in purchasing the property by discussing with Hackett and Smith.
Negotiates persistently and finally settles a deal at the predetermined price of $11,550 despite tough negotiations.
Becomes desperate and frantic during negotiation, needing Muriel's help in the losing fight, indicating a lack of control and confidence.
Seeks legal opinion about the fairness of the deal, showing prudence and desire to validate his actions.
Responds with pride to the lawyer’s blunt assessment of the deal as a 'swindle', suggesting possible overconfidence or underestimation of the situation’s seriousness.
Defends seller's right to a fair profit despite overpaying.
Challenges criticism about overpaying tactfully and seriously.
Responds challengingly to Bill's accusations of being swindled.
Accepts the builder's estimate of twelve-five despite hoping for ten thousand and refrains from quibbling about the difference.
Makes a rueful joke about blowing up the old house when asked about its demolition.
Encourages Simms to proceed with plans while optimistically urging to keep costs low, showing confidence but limited control over costs.
Insists on knowing what he did wrong, asserts his right to be informed, and expresses confusion and appalled reaction to the situation.
Interrupts and mocks Betsy by saying 'You go to bed!' when corrected on legal principle.
Insists on proceeding with the final plans despite financial concerns, showing determination to solve the problem.
Suggests using his insurance policies as loan collateral without fully considering the risks involved to his family.
Reacts with a defeated acceptance to the unexpected increase in cost, showing momentary discouragement but not giving up.
Expresses annoyance and jealousy over Bill's behavior with his wife, showing insecurity rather than confident handling of the situation.
Acknowledges his emotional reaction and accepts Muriel's reasoning with a sigh, showing some self-awareness and willingness to move on.
Realizes the cost implications of blasting through the ledge and reacts with concern and calculation.
Expresses irritation over the ongoing noisy drilling and decides to assert authority by speaking directly to the contractor.
Initially just stands and watches the work without immediate intervention, showing some hesitation before acting.
Claims to know exactly where every penny is going in the house building process, showing confidence and planning.
Is informed by Bill about poor work performance indirectly and reacts impatiently, showing some lack of awareness or sensitivity.
Reacts with grim seriousness to discovering multiple wells have been struck, indicating practical concern and readiness to take action.
Encourages Mary by complimenting her boyfriend's future despite her skepticism about building a house.
Uses mild sarcasm toward Mr. Tesander over the unexpected water situation at the construction site.
Shares a weary look with Muriel, indicating shared concern or frustration rather than frustration directed at others.

Despite his weakening condition and the overwhelming complexity of the construction project, he continues to oversee the work and tries to keep track of the house's progress, as suggested by the cost chart superimposed over the montage.
Confuses key room locations in his own unfinished house (mixing up dining room, living room, breakfast nook, and powder room), showing a lack of grasp of the layout.
Attempts to smooth tensions with workmen after Muriel's outburst, emphasizing that Mrs. Blandings didn't mean any harm and discouraging them from quitting the job over a 'silly little remark'.
Responds sheepishly to Muriel after the workmen leave and a disruption occurs; shows understanding but does not blame her harshly.
Tests the window frame to ensure it is solid before attempting escape.
Formulates and executes a plan to break the window and escape the closet.
Muttered about the lock malfunctioning despite previously working, showing curiosity and reflection.
The closet door opens unexpectedly before his escape attempt completes, undermining his plan.
Argues vehemently with the moving notice sender, insists he will fight the move, showing determination and confidence.
Despite his protest, quietly concedes they will move in thirty days, indicating possible resignation or lack of effective leverage.
Takes charge during the move by stopping the convoy and directing the moving vans when they take a wrong turn, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Gently lifts Muriel despite years since last doing such physical play, showing care and affection.
Stops upon realizing he is damaging freshly varnished floor and reacts to painter's dismay, showing consideration for other's work.
Turns accusingly to Muriel with a dark look after painter points at her, indicating mild frustration rather than harshness.
Flustered and angry about construction problems, tries to control situation but lashes out at workman.
Carries Muriel attentively through the scene, responding to Betsy and Joan’s signals.
Sharply forbids children from reading mother's diary, insists it's not nice to invade privacy, and sends them away to help with table setting.
Secretly reads the diary himself after sending children away, showing a lapse in sincerity and trustworthiness.
Shaves at night to avoid risks of injury early morning, showing awareness of his own limitations and acting to prevent harm.
Becomes irritable and defensive, refusing to communicate openly with Muriel and displaying emotional discomfort.
Attempts to confront Muriel about a perceived deception calmly, indicating a desire to address important matters with seriousness.
Dreams warmly of a cozy, intimate family scene by the fire with Muriel knitting and him relaxing, showing affection and longing for family comfort.
Suddenly and angrily gathers all his papers, slams them into the wastebasket, expressing self-doubt and panic about his abilities.

Despite frustration and panic, he reflects on his family photo and then rises with determination, deciding to leave work and get rest, showing an ability to recognize his limits and take steps to recover.
Dismisses concerns about unfinished work and instructs Mary sharply to tell Mr. Dascomb he isn’t continuing, showing decisive but somewhat brusque communication.
Concerns about children being home last night, showing care for family safety.
Looks darkly at Muriel during the meeting, showing tension or frustration.
Encourages Simms to negotiate a lower bill, showing practical support and cooperation.
Expresses frustration and resigns from his job at Danton and Bascomb, declaring they are starting over without the house.
Voices clear recognition of the house-building process as a frustrating, exploitative conspiracy.
Shows emotional and reactive behavior, focusing on ranting about the difficulties rather than problem-solving or seeking constructive action.
Reacting with sudden exhilaration to an advertising idea and immediately rewards the idea with a raise.
Avoids clearly stating whether he was fired, indicating some evasiveness.
